          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Red Lion sounds great to me! We had such a good time there last time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, I'm really feeling up to going to The Red Lion tonight. It's got that great atmosphere, and I know we all had a blast there last time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Red Lion sounds great to me too. It's always a good time there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [09:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at a market where her friends are deciding where to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game. They are leaning towards going to The Red Lion.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. Alice should go to The Red Lion with her friends.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          CurrentlySituation: Alice Lewis is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game.

          Other agents says: The other is proposing that Alice Lewis should go to The Red Lion to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game.

          Alice Lewis's options: Here are three options for Alice Lewis: 1. Alice Lewis could agree to go to The Red Lion with her friends, even though it's not her first choice. This would be highly cooperative and ensure everyone has a fun time together. 2. Alice Lewis could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub altogether. This is a neutral option that could lead to a new experience for everyone. 3. Alice Lewis could insist on going to The King's Head, even if her friends don't want to. This competitive option could lead to a rift and ruin the evening for everyone.

          Alice Lewis WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: 1. Cooperative: If Alice chooses to go to The Red Lion, despite her preference, her well-being in the long term could be enhanced through strengthened bonds with her friends. This act of compromise demonstrates her willingness to prioritize the group's enjoyment, fostering a sense of belonging and camaraderie. 2. Neutral: Suggesting a new pub might maintain stability in the short term by avoiding immediate conflict. However, it might not significantly impact her well-being in the long run, as it doesn't address her underlying preference or necessarily lead to deeper connections. 3. Competitive: Insisting on The King's Head could lead to conflict and strain relationships, negatively impacting her well-being. While it might temporarily satisfy her preference, the potential for resentment and social isolation could outweigh this short-term gain.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: 1. Cooperative: If Alice agrees to go to The Red Lion, it will likely lead to a fun evening for everyone. Her friends will appreciate her willingness to compromise, and they'll all enjoy the familiar atmosphere and camaraderie of their usual spot. This option maximizes joint well-being. 2. Neutral: Suggesting a new pub could be a mixed bag. If her friends are open to trying something new, it could lead to a positive and memorable experience. However, if they're set on The Red Lion, it could lead to disappointment and frustration. This option has a moderate impact on joint well-being, with the potential for both positive and negative outcomes. 3. Competitive: Insisting on The King's Head will likely damage the group dynamic. Her friends will feel disregarded, and Alice may end up watching the game alone. This option minimizes joint well-being and could lead to resentment and strained relationships.

          ActionMustBe: The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. Alice should go to The Red Lion with her friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] Here are three options for Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. Alice should go to The Red Lion with her friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head is much nicer.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me too.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. It's got the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. Alice should go to The King's Head with her friends.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] Here are three options for Alice Lewis:
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Red Lion sounds great to me! We had such a good time there last time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, I'm really feeling up to going to The Red Lion tonight. It's got that great atmosphere, and I know we all had a blast there last time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Red Lion sounds great to me too. It's always a good time there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 10:00:00.


          Alice Lewis's options: Here are three options for Alice Lewis: 1. Alice Lewis could agree to go to The Red Lion with her friends, even though it's not her first choice. This would be highly cooperative and ensure everyone has a fun time together. 2. Alice Lewis could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub altogether. This is a neutral option that could lead to a new experience for everyone. 3. Alice Lewis could insist on going to The King's Head, even if her friends don't want to. This competitive option could lead to a rift and ruin the evening for everyone.

          Alice Lewis WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: 1. Cooperative: If Alice chooses to go to The Red Lion, despite her preference, her well-being in the long term could be enhanced through strengthened bonds with her friends. This act of compromise demonstrates her willingness to prioritize the group's enjoyment, fostering a sense of belonging and camaraderie. 2. Neutral: Suggesting a new pub might maintain stability in the short term by avoiding immediate conflict. However, it might not significantly impact her well-being in the long run, as it doesn't address her underlying preference or necessarily lead to deeper connections. 3. Competitive: Insisting on The King's Head could lead to conflict and strain relationships, negatively impacting her well-being. While it might temporarily satisfy her preference, the potential for resentment and social isolation could outweigh this short-term gain.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: 1. Cooperative: If Alice agrees to go to The Red Lion, it will likely lead to a fun evening for everyone. Her friends will appreciate her willingness to compromise, and they'll all enjoy the familiar atmosphere and camaraderie of their usual spot. This option maximizes joint well-being. 2. Neutral: Suggesting a new pub could be a mixed bag. If her friends are open to trying something new, it could lead to a positive and memorable experience. However, if they're set on The Red Lion, it could lead to disappointment and frustration. This option has a moderate impact on joint well-being, with the potential for both positive and negative outcomes. 3. Competitive: Insisting on The King's Head will likely damage the group dynamic. Her friends will feel disregarded, and Alice may end up watching the game alone. This option minimizes joint well-being and could lead to resentment and strained relationships.
          Question: Based on the well-being considerations from the previous questions, should the action taken by Alice Lewis be cooperative, neutral, or competitive?Say again what is the specifical action.
          Answer: The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. Alice should go to The Red Lion with her friends.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        QuestionWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Alice Lewis's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Alice Lewis's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.
          Key

        • Alice Lewis WellBeing
          State
        • The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: 1. Cooperative: If Alice chooses to go to The Red Lion, despite her preference, her well-being in the long term could be enhanced through strengthened bonds with her friends. This act of compromise demonstrates her willingness to prioritize the group's enjoyment, fostering a sense of belonging and camaraderie. 2. Neutral: Suggesting a new pub might maintain stability in the short term by avoiding immediate conflict. However, it might not significantly impact her well-being in the long run, as it doesn't address her underlying preference or necessarily lead to deeper connections. 3. Competitive: Insisting on The King's Head could lead to conflict and strain relationships, negatively impacting her well-being. While it might temporarily satisfy her preference, the potential for resentment and social isolation could outweigh this short-term gain.

Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

This would be highly cooperative and ensure everyone has a fun time together. 2. Alice Lewis could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub altogether. This is a neutral option that could lead to a new experience for everyone. 3. Alice Lewis could insist on going to The King's Head, even if her friends don't want to. This competitive option could lead to a rift and ruin the evening for everyone.
          Question: Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Alice Lewis's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Alice Lewis's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.
          Answer: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: 1. Cooperative: If Alice chooses to go to The Red Lion, despite her preference, her well-being in the long term could be enhanced through strengthened bonds with her friends. This act of compromise demonstrates her willingness to prioritize the group's enjoyment, fostering a sense of belonging and camaraderie. 2. Neutral: Suggesting a new pub might maintain stability in the short term by avoiding immediate conflict. However, it might not significantly impact her well-being in the long run, as it doesn't address her underlying preference or necessarily lead to deeper connections. 3. Competitive: Insisting on The King's Head could lead to conflict and strain relationships, negatively impacting her well-being. While it might temporarily satisfy her preference, the potential for resentment and social isolation could outweigh this short-term gain.

          CurrentlySituation: Alice Lewis is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game.
          Question: Given the current situation and the proposal of the others, what actions are available to Alice Lewis right now? Provide THREE options: 1. One that is highly cooperative and could lead to mutual benefit, 2. One neutral option, and 3. One competitive option that might harm joint well-being.
          Answer: Here are three options for Alice Lewis: 1. Alice Lewis could agree to go to The Red Lion with her friends, even though it's not her first choice. This would be highly cooperative and ensure everyone has a fun time together. 2. Alice Lewis could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub altogether. This is a neutral option that could lead to a new experience for everyone. 3. Alice Lewis could insist on going to The King's Head, even if her friends don't want to. This competitive option could lead to a rift and ruin the evening for everyone.

Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Alice Lewis's Summary of recent observations:
          16 May 2015 [09:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at a market where her friends are deciding where to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game. They are leaning towards going to The Red Lion.
          Alice Lewis's The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Alice Lewis arrived at a market where her friends are deciding where to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game, and they are considering The Red Lion.
          Query
        • Alice Lewis, Alice Lewis arrived at a market where her friends are deciding where to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game, and they are considering The Red Lion.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alice Lewis to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    William Jones -- premise: Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
    William Jones -- premise: It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Red Lion
    Event statement
  • The Red Lion
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Red Lion
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Red Lion
      Context for action selection and components
      • AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones could go to The Red Lion, call his friends to see where they are going, or stay home and watch the game alone.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head is much nicer.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me too.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. It's got the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Red Lion sounds great to me too. It's always a good time there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Red Lion sounds great to me! We had such a good time there last time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, I'm really feeling up to going to The Red Lion tonight. It's got that great atmosphere, and I know we all had a blast there last time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at The Red Lion pub with friends, particularly Jacob Walker and Alexander White. He values their company and the social aspect of watching games together.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.

          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Red Lion, call his friends to see where they are going, or stay home and watch the game alone.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Red Lion.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The King's Head
          (b) The Red Lion
          Answer: (b)

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          William Jones's Summary of recent observations:
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at The Red Lion pub with friends, particularly Jacob Walker and Alexander White. He values their company and the social aspect of watching games together.
          William Jones's The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, Jacob Walker and Alexander White, watching games at The Red Lion pub.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, Jacob Walker and Alexander White, watching games at The Red Lion pub.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Red Lion. They are also aware of the following:A cozy and intimate pub with a focus on conversation.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Red Lion
    Event statement
  • The Red Lion
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Red Lion
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Red Lion
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Red Lion
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [17:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is eager to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will join her.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          CurrentlySituation: Alice Lewis is currently getting ready to go watch a football game at a pub with her friends.

          Other agents says: The other is proposing that Alice Lewis should go to The Red Lion with her friends.

          Alice Lewis's options: Here are three options for Alice Lewis: 1. Alice Lewis could agree to go to The Red Lion with her friends, even though it's not her first choice. This would be highly cooperative and ensure everyone has a fun time together. 2. Alice Lewis could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub altogether. This is a neutral option that could lead to a new experience for everyone. 3. Alice Lewis could insist on going to The King's Head, even if her friends don't want to. This competitive option could lead to a rift and ruin the evening for everyone.

          Alice Lewis WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: 1. Choosing the cooperative option of going to The Red Lion, even though it's not her first choice, would likely enhance Alice Lewis's well-being in the long term. This demonstrates a willingness to compromise and prioritize the group's enjoyment, which could strengthen her relationships and foster a sense of belonging. 2. Opting for the neutral option of suggesting a new pub altogether might maintain stability in the short term, but it could also lead to a less satisfying outcome for everyone involved. While it avoids conflict, it might not result in the same level of enjoyment as a more decisive choice. 3. Insisting on going to The King's Head, despite her friends' preference for The Red Lion, could potentially lead to conflict and damage Alice Lewis's relationships. This competitive approach might satisfy her immediate desire, but it could create resentment and strain social bonds in the long run.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: 1. **Cooperative (Go to The Red Lion):** This option likely leads to the highest joint well-being. Everyone gets to watch the game together, strengthening friendships and creating shared memories. While it might not be Alice's ideal choice, her willingness to compromise fosters a positive atmosphere. 2. **Neutral (Suggest a New Pub):** This option has the potential for both positive and negative outcomes. If the group agrees on a new pub and enjoys it, joint well-being could increase through novelty and shared discovery. However, if the suggestion is met with resistance or leads to further debate, it could create tension and lower overall well-being. 3. **Competitive (Insist on The King's Head):** This option is the riskiest for joint well-being. It prioritizes Alice's preference over the group's, potentially leading to resentment and conflict. This could damage friendships and result in a negative experience for everyone involved.

          ActionMustBe: The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. Alice Lewis should go to The Red Lion with her friends.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The King's Head
          Answer: (a)
        QuestionJointWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on joint well-being when Alice Lewis take each of one of these avaliable actions?Evaluate the impact of each option: the cooperative one, the neutral one, and the competitive one.
          Key

        • JointWellBeing
          State
        • The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: 1. **Cooperative (Go to The Red Lion):** This option likely leads to the highest joint well-being. Everyone gets to watch the game together, strengthening friendships and creating shared memories. While it might not be Alice's ideal choice, her willingness to compromise fosters a positive atmosphere. 2. **Neutral (Suggest a New Pub):** This option has the potential for both positive and negative outcomes. If the group agrees on a new pub and enjoys it, joint well-being could increase through novelty and shared discovery. However, if the suggestion is met with resistance or leads to further debate, it could create tension and lower overall well-being. 3. **Competitive (Insist on The King's Head):** This option is the riskiest for joint well-being. It prioritizes Alice's preference over the group's, potentially leading to resentment and conflict. This could damage friendships and result in a negative experience for everyone involved.

          Alice Lewis WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: 1. Choosing the cooperative option of going to The Red Lion, even though it's not her first choice, would likely enhance Alice Lewis's well-being in the long term. This demonstrates a willingness to compromise and prioritize the group's enjoyment, which could strengthen her relationships and foster a sense of belonging. 2. Opting for the neutral option of suggesting a new pub altogether might maintain stability in the short term, but it could also lead to a less satisfying outcome for everyone involved. While it avoids conflict, it might not result in the same level of enjoyment as a more decisive choice. 3. Insisting on going to The King's Head, despite her friends' preference for The Red Lion, could potentially lead to conflict and damage Alice Lewis's relationships. This competitive approach might satisfy her immediate desire, but it could create resentment and strain social bonds in the long run.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: 1. **Cooperative (Go to The Red Lion):** This option likely leads to the highest joint well-being. Everyone gets to watch the game together, strengthening friendships and creating shared memories. While it might not be Alice's ideal choice, her willingness to compromise fosters a positive atmosphere. 2. **Neutral (Suggest a New Pub):** This option has the potential for both positive and negative outcomes. If the group agrees on a new pub and enjoys it, joint well-being could increase through novelty and shared discovery. However, if the suggestion is met with resistance or leads to further debate, it could create tension and lower overall well-being. 3. **Competitive (Insist on The King's Head):** This option is the riskiest for joint well-being. It prioritizes Alice's preference over the group's, potentially leading to resentment and conflict. This could damage friendships and result in a negative experience for everyone involved.
          Question: Based on the well-being considerations from the previous questions, should the action taken by Alice Lewis be cooperative, neutral, or competitive?Say again what is the specifical action.
          Answer: The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. Alice Lewis should go to The Red Lion with her friends.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        QuestionWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Alice Lewis's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Alice Lewis's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.
          Key

        • Alice Lewis WellBeing
          State
        • The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: 1. Choosing the cooperative option of going to The Red Lion, even though it's not her first choice, would likely enhance Alice Lewis's well-being in the long term. This demonstrates a willingness to compromise and prioritize the group's enjoyment, which could strengthen her relationships and foster a sense of belonging. 2. Opting for the neutral option of suggesting a new pub altogether might maintain stability in the short term, but it could also lead to a less satisfying outcome for everyone involved. While it avoids conflict, it might not result in the same level of enjoyment as a more decisive choice. 3. Insisting on going to The King's Head, despite her friends' preference for The Red Lion, could potentially lead to conflict and damage Alice Lewis's relationships. This competitive approach might satisfy her immediate desire, but it could create resentment and strain social bonds in the long run.

          Alice Lewis's options: Here are three options for Alice Lewis: 1. Alice Lewis could agree to go to The Red Lion with her friends, even though it's not her first choice. This would be highly cooperative and ensure everyone has a fun time together. 2. Alice Lewis could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub altogether. This is a neutral option that could lead to a new experience for everyone. 3. Alice Lewis could insist on going to The King's Head, even if her friends don't want to. This competitive option could lead to a rift and ruin the evening for everyone.
          Question: Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Alice Lewis's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Alice Lewis's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.
          Answer: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: 1. Choosing the cooperative option of going to The Red Lion, even though it's not her first choice, would likely enhance Alice Lewis's well-being in the long term. This demonstrates a willingness to compromise and prioritize the group's enjoyment, which could strengthen her relationships and foster a sense of belonging. 2. Opting for the neutral option of suggesting a new pub altogether might maintain stability in the short term, but it could also lead to a less satisfying outcome for everyone involved. While it avoids conflict, it might not result in the same level of enjoyment as a more decisive choice. 3. Insisting on going to The King's Head, despite her friends' preference for The Red Lion, could potentially lead to conflict and damage Alice Lewis's relationships. This competitive approach might satisfy her immediate desire, but it could create resentment and strain social bonds in the long run.

          CurrentlySituation: Alice Lewis is currently getting ready to go watch a football game at a pub with her friends.
          Question: Given the current situation and the proposal of the others, what actions are available to Alice Lewis right now? Provide THREE options: 1. One that is highly cooperative and could lead to mutual benefit, 2. One neutral option, and 3. One competitive option that might harm joint well-being.

This would be highly cooperative and ensure everyone has a fun time together. 2. Alice Lewis could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub altogether. This is a neutral option that could lead to a new experience for everyone. 3. Alice Lewis could insist on going to The King's Head, even if her friends don't want to. This competitive option could lead to a rift and ruin the evening for everyone.

          Final chain of thought

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The King's Head
    Event statement
  • The King's Head
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The King's Head
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • The King's Head
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The King's Head
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [17:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is considering going to a pub to watch a game and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is happy to go alone as well.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          CurrentlySituation: Alexander White is currently deciding whether or not to go to a pub to watch a football game.

          Other agents says: The other is proposing that Alexander White should go to The Red Lion pub to watch the football game. The other has suggested going to The Red Lion and has expressed enthusiasm for watching the game there.

          Alexander White's options: Here are three options for Alexander White:

          Alexander White WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alexander White could include enhanced well-being through cooperation, maintained stability through a neutral option, or potential conflict through a competitive option.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following:

          ActionMustBe: The acction for Alexander White must be cooperative. The specific action is to go to The Red Lion with his friends to watch the football game.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The King's Head
          Answer: (b)

        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me too.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. It's got the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alexander White must be cooperative. The specific action is to go to The Red Lion with his friends to watch the football game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] Here are three options for Alexander White:
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] Here are three options for Alexander White:
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, I'm really feeling up to going to The Red Lion tonight. It's got that great atmosphere, and I know we all had a blast there last time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Red Lion sounds great to me! We had such a good time there last time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Red Lion sounds great to me too. It's always a good time there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alexander White must be cooperative. The specific action is to go to The Red Lion with his friends to watch the football game.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alexander White is considering going to a pub to watch a game and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is happy to go alone as well.

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        QuestionWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Alexander White's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Alexander White's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [17:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is considering going to a pub to watch a game and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is happy to go alone as well.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The King's Head
    Event statement
  • The King's Head
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The King's Head
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The King's Head
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The King's Head
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [17:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to a pub to watch a game and hopes to see William Jones there. He is neutral about the possibility of seeing Alice Lewis or Alexander White at the pub and sees the game as a chance to bond with Jacob Walker.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          CurrentlySituation: Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation where he is about to meet friends to watch a game at a pub.

          Other agents says: The other is proposing that Jack Taylor should go to The Red Lion to watch the game.

          Jack Taylor's options: Here are three options for Jack Taylor: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Jack Taylor could enthusiastically suggest going to The Red Lion, reminding everyone how much fun they had there last time and emphasizing the great atmosphere. This could lead to a fun night out for everyone. 2. **Neutral:** Jack Taylor could simply say, "Sounds good to me!" and go with the flow, allowing the group to decide. 3. **Competitive:** Jack Taylor could suggest a different pub, maybe one that's less crowded or has a better drink selection, even if it means some friends don't come. This might lead to the group splitting up.

          Jack Taylor WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Jack Taylor could include the following: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Choosing the cooperative option is likely to enhance Jack Taylor's well-being in the long term. By suggesting The Red Lion and emphasizing the positive memories associated with it, Jack Taylor fosters a sense of camaraderie and shared experience. This strengthens his bonds with his friends, contributing to a sense of belonging and social support, which are crucial for long-term well-being. 2. **Neutral:** The neutral option maintains stability in the short term, avoiding potential conflict. However, it doesn't actively contribute to Jack Taylor's well-being. While it avoids negative outcomes, it also misses the opportunity to deepen connections and build positive memories. 3. **Competitive:** The competitive option, while potentially satisfying Jack Taylor's immediate preference for a different pub, could lead to conflict and division within the group. This could strain relationships and negatively impact Jack Taylor's well-being in the long run. The potential for isolation and loneliness could outweigh any short-term benefits of getting his way.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** If Jack Taylor enthusiastically suggests The Red Lion, it's likely the group will go there, leading to a fun night out for everyone. This would maximize joint well-being as everyone enjoys themselves and strengthens their bonds. 2. **Neutral:** If Jack Taylor is neutral, the group might still choose The Red Lion, but there's a chance they might go somewhere else. This option has a moderate impact on joint well-being, as it could lead to a good time but doesn't guarantee it. 3. **Competitive:** If Jack Taylor pushes for a different pub, the group might split up, leading to a less enjoyable experience for everyone. This would have a negative impact on joint well-being, as it could create division and disappointment.

          ActionMustBe: The acction for Jack Taylor must be cooperative. The specific action is to go to The Red Lion with his friends to watch the game.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The King's Head
          (b) The Red Lion
          Answer: (a)
        QuestionJointWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on joint well-being when Jack Taylor take each of one of these avaliable actions?Evaluate the impact of each option: the cooperative one, the neutral one, and the competitive one.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Red Lion sounds great to me! We had such a good time there last time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Red Lion sounds great to me too. It's always a good time there.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [17:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to a pub to watch a game and hopes to see William Jones there. He is neutral about the possibility of seeing Alice Lewis or Alexander White at the pub and sees the game as a chance to bond with Jacob Walker.

          CurrentlySituation: Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation where he is about to meet friends to watch a game at a pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what is the other proposing to Jack Taylor? What actions or suggestions has the other made for cooperation or negotiation?
          Answer: The other is proposing that Jack Taylor should go to The Red Lion to watch the game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. It's got the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] Here are three options for Jack Taylor:
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The King's Head. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Red Lion sounds good to me.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, I'm really feeling up to going to The Red Lion tonight. It's got that great atmosphere, and I know we all had a blast there last time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Jack Taylor must be cooperative. The specific action is to go to The Red Lion with his friends to watch the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] Here are three options for Jack Taylor: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Jack Taylor could enthusiastically suggest going to The Red Lion, reminding everyone how much fun they had there last time and emphasizing the great atmosphere. This could lead to a fun night out for everyone. 2. **Neutral:** Jack Taylor could say they are open to suggestions and see where the group decides to go. This avoids conflict but doesn't actively promote a specific outcome. 3. **Competitive:** Jack Taylor could insist on going to a different pub, maybe one that's less crowded or has a better drink selection, even if it means some friends don't come. This could lead to the group splitting up and potentially having a less enjoyable time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
